Exercise 11.7

Let (rn)\p{r_n}(rn​) be an enumeration of the set Q\QQ of all rational numbers. Show there exists a subsequence (rnk)\p{r_{n_k}}(rnk​​) such that lim⁡k→∞rnk=+∞\lim_{k\to\infty} r_{n_k} = +\inftylimk→∞​rnk​​=+∞.

Solution.

I will give two solutions--one that just uses a theorem, and one that's more explicit in the construction. Either is fine, of course, but I suggest you understand the explicit construction.

Solution 1 (by Theorem 11.2)

Q\QQ is unbounded (e.g., N⊆Q\N \subseteq \QN⊆Q), so because (rn)\p{r_n}(rn​) is an enumeration of Q\QQ, it follows that (rn)\p{r_n}(rn​) itself is unbounded. Thus, by THeorem 11.2(ii), there exists a subsequence which diverges to +∞+\infty+∞.

Since (rn)\p{r_n}(rn​) is unbounded, 111 is not an upper bound for (rn)\p{r_n}(rn​). Thus, there exists n1∈Nn_1 \in \Nn1​∈N such that rn1≥1r_{n_1} \geq 1rn1​​≥1.

is still an unbounded set since we only remove finitely many elements. Thus, in particular, k+1k + 1k+1 is not an upper bound for SkS_kSk​, so there exists rnk+1∈Skr_{n_{k+1}} \in S_krnk+1​​∈Sk​ such that rnk+1≥k+1r_{n_{k+1}} \geq k + 1rnk+1​​≥k+1. Thus, we have shown that there exists a subsequence (rnk)\p{r_{n_k}}(rnk​​) such that rnk≥kr_{n_k} \geq krnk​​≥k, which implies rnk→+∞r_{n_k} \to +\inftyrnk​​→+∞.
